ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A variety of approaches and studies in the field of cognitive science of morality.
You learn about the psychological processes and philosophical thought behind morality. Dr. Knobe is an incredible seminar leader.
Broad theoretical frameworks of moral cognition, and also interesting connections of moral cognition to various topics (law, dev psych, etc)

I gained a deeper insight into how work, methods, and theories in cognitive science can be used to explore human morality and moral decision-making. I was able to develop, run, and report on my own study which is one of the best academic experiences I have had at Yale.
I got a fascinating overview about various themes within Cognitive Science and the the questions asked/methodologies used to understand morality.
Insights into the interdisciplinary approaches (psychology, philosophy, development, legal, etc.) for understanding the cognitive science of morality.
Learned the main ideas and theories in the psychology of morality through reading important papers.

An understanding of various broad theories about moral cognition and moral intuitions specifically, understanding of how researchers go about answering questions in this field, applications from moral cognition for experimental philosophy, developmental psychology, economics, and experimental jurisprudence (among other areas), how to think critically about experimental design and results, and genuinely so much more. This course teaches vital skills that are useful in any academic discipline, and will demonstrate the need for interdisciplinary cooperation to make progress in answering many particularly challenging questions

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It is just a challenging class because it's so high-level. However, it is super interesting.
Strengths are Dr. Knobe and the students. There are no weaknesses
Professor Knobe does an excellent job curating readings and discussions. Super engaging course.
I appreciate how Josh let the conversation go where it did according to whatever was on students' minds (lots of freedom), but sometimes conversation tapered off.

The course was great! I enjoyed the format of providing a brief response before class to get things moving. Sometimes, it was difficult to know where to jump into the conversation when the discussion changed rapidly, but overall it was a great experience.

It is a great set-up with a low workload and interesting seminar meetings. I liked the students don't have to present papers like in many other psych seminas. There are big expectations for the final project so I think that the proposal should be mandatory and there should be feedback given on our plan earlier.

Everything about this course is absolutely wonderful! From the very first class, Josh took steps to help students feel at ease and create a space that felt collaborative and generative for ideas from everyone (including through not have students say whether they're an undergrad or graduate student, saying that we could call him Josh, and taking time in the first class and the beginning of each class to ensure that students understood the relevant background knowledge to discuss a particular paper or theme). The content of this course is incredibly fascinating, and Josh is also very willing to change the syllabus in order to better accommodate students' interests (which wasn't just something he said, but actually ended up doing, including by polling students on which topic they would prefer to discuss in an upcoming week). Even during the discussions themselves, Josh was amazingly open to allowing the conversation to shift and change direction based on student interest, leading to some fascinating and unexpected discussions. I have never had a seminar where the class time flew by so quickly. I have never had a seminar where the professor created such an uplifting environment for student contributions across disciplines and experience levels, including in-person classes (let alone over Zoom). Each class you will come away with genuine insights and further thoughts on the material, and you will be amazed at the intelligence of the other students and of Josh. It is extremely rare to find a professor who is so brilliant and knowledgeable in his field (there's literally an incredible discovery that has inspired a huge amount of literature in the field called the "Knobe Effect" - you get one guess for who discovered it) yet so welcoming, generous with his time, and invested in student learning and success. While the final project might seem intimidating, don't let it be. Josh somehow manages to find the time to meet with students and talk through their ideas with them in between all his other responsibilities, which is an absolutely crazy opportunity to take advantage of and talk one-on-one with such an insanely knowledgeable professor. During a semester filled with stress from so many different areas and a general sense of discontentment with the academic loss of learning over Zoom, this class was an incredibly rich, thought-provoking, and enriching experience that I was excited to participate in every week and was actually sad to see end. If you can get into this course, take it without a doubt or a moment's hesitation. If you have the opportunity to take any course ever with Josh Knobe, take it without a moment's hesitation. I wish that I could have a class with him every semester. It is amazing to come away from a class thinking that there is literally nothing that could have been changed to make it any better. The other students in the class, the material, the discussions, the format of the class, the form of assessment, and the instructor are all absolutely fantastic. You will never find another class at Yale quite like this one or a professor as insightful and kind as Josh.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Josh is a great instructor; he handled the online learning environment quite well.
Since it was virtual, the length of the seminar was hard to sit through because of Zoom fatigue. Other than that, fantastic discussions
The virtual format of the seminar was not an impediment to my learning and felt no different from a normal course.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely. Amazing class.
Yes!!!
Absolutely  Prof knobe is a brilliant educator and this course is a delight.
Yes, cool topic, but discussion dependent on who is in the course

Yes, this is a wonderful course for exploring cognitive science more fully and getting a chance to contribute to the field with an immersive final project. If you do not want to develop your own project/original work in the field, do not take the course. However, if you start early and delve into something you are genuinely interested in, you will learn so much more than regular lecture courses. It was one of the best courses I have taken at Yale!

Yes. Morality encompasses much of everyday life in ways that aren't consciously thought of. This course allowed me to think deeply about moral questions and prompted me to form questions and answers of my own. This class hinges upon class discussion and creates a nice space to share thoughts and opinions on moral issues.

It is a great course for those interested in social psychology, and is much more of a psychology than philosophy class. Knobe is a great seminar leader as he engages deeply with everyone's ideas in a friendly and helpful way.

Everything about this course is absolutely wonderful! From the very first class, Josh took steps to help students feel at ease and create a space that felt collaborative and generative for ideas from everyone (including through not have students say whether they're an undergrad or graduate student, saying that we could call him Josh, and taking time in the first class and the beginning of each class to ensure that students understood the relevant background knowledge to discuss a particular paper or theme). The content of this course is incredibly fascinating, and Josh is also very willing to change the syllabus in order to better accommodate students' interests (which wasn't just something he said, but actually ended up doing, including by polling students on which topic they would prefer to discuss in an upcoming week). Even during the discussions themselves, Josh was amazingly open to allowing the conversation to shift and change direction based on student interest, leading to some fascinating and unexpected discussions. I have never had a seminar where the class time flew by so quickly. I have never had a seminar where the professor created such an uplifting environment for student contributions across disciplines and experience levels, including in-person classes (let alone over Zoom). Each class you will come away with genuine insights and further thoughts on the material, and you will be amazed at the intelligence of the other students and of Josh. It is extremely rare to find a professor who is so brilliant and knowledgeable in his field (there's literally an incredible discovery that has inspired a huge amount of literature in the field called the "Knobe Effect" - you get one guess for who discovered it) yet so welcoming, generous with his time, and invested in student learning and success. Josh somehow manages to find the time to meet with students and talk through their ideas with them in between all his other responsibilities, which is an absolutely crazy opportunity to take advantage of and talk one-on-one with such an insanely knowledgeable professor. During a semester filled with stress from so many different areas and a general sense of discontentment with the academic loss of learning over Zoom, this class was an incredibly rich, thought-provoking, and enriching experience that I was excited to participate in every week and was actually sad to see end. If you can get into this course, take it without a doubt or a moment's hesitation. If you have the opportunity to take any course ever with Josh Knobe, take it without a moment's hesitation. I wish that I could have a class with him every semester. It is amazing to come away from a class thinking that there is literally nothing that could have been changed to make it any better. The other students in the class, the material, the discussions, the format of the class, the form of assessment, and the instructor are all absolutely fantastic. You will never find another class at Yale quite like this one or a professor as insightful and kind as Josh.
